questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which action is taken by the router when a packet is sourced from 10.10.10.2 and destined for 10.10.10.16?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer is correct.
10.10.10.16 is not in the defined subnet range I.e. 10.10.10.0/28 and since default gateway is not set, packets to the undefined destination address will be dropped.
correct. is D.

Selected Answer: D
10.10.10.0/28 seems almost valid :)
range 0-15
10.10.10.16 is out of range, no valid route

Selected Answer: D
D. It discards the packets.
There's no route to the destination so it discards the packets.

comments.content: my bad, the answer is D

Easy way to remember is that all broadcast addresses are an odd number.
As .16 isn't odd, it can't be a B/C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
This is broadcast address, and it will be routed to closest route matching the subnet.

choices.A: It floods packets to all learned next hops.
choices.B: It uses a route that is similar to the destination address.
choices.C: It queues the packets waiting for the route to be learned.

comments.content:

externalBGP: 20

InternalBGP: 200

some other AD's to remember...
Connected route: 0

Very annoying question.
It should be translated as "Static route will be used if: all protocols are up and/or eBGP&EIGRP&OSPF are down (but not the static route)" and the same for the routing protocols (BGP learned route will be used if: static route is down... and so on)

discussion.content: can someone tell me what is right answer for this. I think I lost in this question
The answers are correct
Given answers are correct
in EIGRP, the eBGP route will be down because it is routed in the same AS(autonomous system)?
I got this question on my exam last month
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/border-gateway-protocol-bgp/15986-admin-distance.html

Directly connected interface 0
Static route 1
Dynamic Mobile Network Routing (DMNR) 3
EIGRP summary route 5
External BGP 20
EIGRP internal route 90
IGRP 100
Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) 110
Intermediate System to Intermediate System (IS-IS) 115
Routing Information Protocol (RIP) 120
Exterior Gateway Protocol (EGP) 140
ODR 160
EIGRP external route 170
Internal BGP 200
Next Hop Resolution Protocol (NHRP) 250[6]
Default static route learned via DHCP 254[citation needed]
Unknown and unused 255[b]
Its basically asking what would happen based on the routing methods used. so if and interface is using ebgp all other routing options will be down.

Selected Answer: B
B is Absolutely Correct!!!

Selected Answer: B
Floating static defalut route must have a higher AD so B is the only correct answers.

comments.content: Static Route AD = 1 so the answer cannot be A.
the question is for a floating static default route (backup), therefore "B" is correct with route cost 10

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure a core router with a floating static default route to the backup router at 10.200.0.2. Which command meets the requirements?
Why was the RFC 1918 address space defined?

choices.D: reduce instances of overlapping IP addresses

discussion.content: A is correct. Private IPv4 addresses were developed to conserve IPv4 address space. NAT was developed as a way to use private addresses and allow for them to be able to communicate with other hosts outside of their LAN. C & D do not deal at all with private IP addresses

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A. RFC 1918 was about private ipv4 addressing
What is the difference between A and C?

comments.content: ipv6 doesnt need any preservation or conservation. It's got a metric fuck ton to the power of bazillion addresses. Whereas ipv4 is essentially already depleted.

discussion.content: A is correct!

A is correct


An RFC1918 address is an IP address that is assigned by an enterprise organization to an internal host. These IP addresses are used in private networks, which are not available, or reachable, from the Internet.

Answer is A.

"With the described scheme many large enterprises will need only a
 relatively small block of addresses from the globally unique IP
 address space."
